text: Yeah, it's a great question. Maybe before we get into the answer, let me define a market shock and what I mean by that. So a market shock is a big spike in volatility. Maybe we'll define that as a move in the VIX index of five points or more. I'm just making this up, but let's let's use that criteria. But if we use that criteria, five point daily move in the VIX. When I look at the 10 years prior to the global financial crisis, there were only five days of those 10 years in which the VIX spiked more than five points. OK, so pretty rare. Since the global financial crisis, there have been 56 of these volatility shocks. Seven of them have occurred in the last couple of months. What we can see by this is that the volatility dynamic of the VIX is very, very high. The equity market is changing materially. It's not necessarily the level of the volatility that's changing. What is changing is the skewness or that third moment of the distribution, meaning that when drawdowns occur, they tend to be more severe than they have been in the past. Now, typically in a volatility spike, there's a significant drawdown followed by also a significant rebound. And we're seeing more and more evidence of this kind of activity. This is important because this means that the volatility is going to be more severe. This means there is more tail risk in the equity portfolio as a result of it. So what's driving that to your question? There's a number of things I think that are driving this. Over the last few months, certainly coronavirus, obviously rising recession probability is associated with coronavirus. But it's bigger than that. One of the considerations that I think is significant is globally, from a central bank perspective, we have a very low interest rate, even a negative interest rate policy. And that's a very significant factor for many countries. This has increased the level of leverage that we see in the economy. And you can almost trace it. If you look at the graphs, there is commensurate increase in volatility spikes related to the level of leverage that we see in the global economy. So that's another consideration. A third and very important one as well is that, as everyone knows, today trading is computer dominated. And you have. A lot more. And I was formerly an algorithmic trader myself. You have a lot more algos that are doing things like volatility selling or trying to capitalize on the difference between realized and implied volatility. Whatever form it comes, many of these algos have these natural off switches. So if a spike occurs or a shock occurs in the market, liquidity tends to dry up, exacerbating a lot of these drawdowns. When it rebounds. Right. Or when it goes back, those off switches turn back to on and that helps the float the rebound, if you will. So I think some of the tail risk absolutely tied to the way the microstructure of the market sits today. It's important because, as you know, I think I mentioned this already. When you look at the asset allocation of a portfolio, even though maybe 60% of your assets are in equity, virtually 100% of your tail risk is in equity. And from a just a risk perspective, 80 to 90% of your total risk is in equity. So 60% of your assets, 80 to 90% of your risk, 100% of your tail risk, that's becoming more pronounced. That's something we have to deal with. And factors like quality and low volatility are ideally suited for this and that they can cut the tail risk but not operate purely as low beta, meaning that you're going to cut the return when the market rebounds. So you can craft an asymmetric. Beta profile with the right combination of quality and volatility. So protect on the downside, participate in the upside.
